Text.Value: Hmmm.

EditorData.NodeContext: Looking down at the table in front of him, studying something

Text.Value: Do what you can to protect the people of Baldur's Gate.
He was never going to show me the secrets of Ramazith's Tower. Instead, he'd merely string me along - like a faithful cub.
Forgive me - I am in the middle of a most interesting speculation on alchemical blood.

EditorData.NodeContext: Looking down - studying something. Wishes to be left in peace.

Text.Value: Why, my friend, we take what's ours.
I thought it was the price I had to pay to become a true wizard. I realise now he was just a sick, sick man.

EditorData.NodeContext: eyes closed at the beginning (maybe?) dissapointed in himself for trusting lorroakan

Text.Value: I need time to cage the Nightsong - kindly give me some.

EditorData.NodeContext: touch annoyed at the interruption

Text.Value: You'll be challenged. I'm sure there are others who want the tower.
Lorroakan is dead. The bastard is dead.

EditorData.NodeContext: His master has just died and he helped. Mix of emotions - relieved, angry, disbelief

Text.Value: Thankfully, I have everything I need - right here.

EditorData.NodeContext: big smile, full of pride - gesturing to the magical tower he stands in - he has achieved his dream. Holds arms out wide

Text.Value: You just want Ramazith's Tower for yourself, don't you? No - I refuse to bow to another!

EditorData.NodeContext: about to begin combat

Text.Value: I think not.
Study and catalogue it - Lorroakan barely knew his alphabet.
What's mine is yours, friend. But you and I just rendered a celestial unconscious. A very angry celestial.
Do you happen to have a soul cage lying about with which to contain the limitless power of a furious aasimar?
A paltry sum for saving you.
It will take time to tame the Nightsong, but we will do it, I have no doubt.

EditorData.NodeContext: more demure and restrained then our usual rolan - he's sided with lorroakan and is now his eternal apprentice

Text.Value: I'll move Lia in immediately. Lorroakan refused to let her stay here. She is going to love the armoury.

EditorData.NodeContext: delight at the thought of showing his family

Text.Value: Look, I just want to get paid.
I'll move Cal in immediately. Lorroakan refused to let him stay here. He is going to love the library.

EditorData.NodeContext: delight at the thought of showing his family

Text.Value: I'm sorry about your master.
Indeed - I must still figure out its intricacies, but I am close.

EditorData.NodeContext: gesturing to the table in front of him

Text.Value: And you'll have me. I'll learn everything I can about the tower in the meantime - even if I have to rip this place apart.

EditorData.NodeContext: determined

Text.Value: I have. With your considerable help.
I wouldn't have this - the tower, my family - without you. What can I do to thank you?

EditorData.NodeContext: sincere and grateful

Text.Value: The Nightsong was a person? Yet he still planned to harvest her life? I shouldn't be surprised.

EditorData.NodeContext: surprise but then brings it back - thinking about his own situation

Text.Value: You let my family die - and then you kill my master? Have you made it your personal mission to ruin my life?

EditorData.NodeContext: disbelief, pain, shock
EditorData.logicalname: Killed Lorroakan before Nightsong - Rolan has no family

Text.Value: You don't understand - I worked my entire life to become Lorroakan's apprentice. And you've ruined it - I can't let you get away with this.

EditorData.NodeContext: sad but determined - he's going to kill the player

Text.Value: I'll let you study in peace.
I have mere notes and scrolls to go by - but if that moron Lorroakan can do it, I doubtless can.
You mean we have all this - the tower is mine as much as yours.
Here. Your fee for bringing the Nightsong to me. Lorroakan used me as his purse-holder - idiot needed his fingers to count.

EditorData.logicalname: Lorroakan knocked out and Rolan has no family

Text.Value: Myself and this tower are now your allies. When the time comes, we will stand by you however necessary.

EditorData.NodeContext: sincere and grateful

Text.Value: Are you all right?
Let them come. I happened across a book on the tower's defences, and they are considerable.

EditorData.NodeContext: a sly smile - a touch of his old arrogance (but in a charming way)

Text.Value: We bested the Nightsong and lived. Lorroakan, however, was not so fortunate.
All hail Rolan, master of Ramazith's Tower.
Thank you. Sincerely.

EditorData.NodeContext: clenched fists, he's delighted lorroakan is dead

Text.Value: Lorroakan was a cruel and vicious man. By day, I'd tend the shop, but at night - he'd fire the most nonsensical questions at me.

EditorData.NodeContext: lost in a painful memory

Text.Value: Same thing that's going to happen to you.
Hardly - it doesn't take a 'great wizard' to see that both men deserved to die. In fact - you've done me a favour.

EditorData.NodeContext: 'you've done me a favour' sad - a bit ashamed at what he's about to explain (about lorroakan beating him)

Text.Value: I'll move Cal and Lia in immediately. Lorroakan refused to let them stay here. They are going to love the tower.

EditorData.NodeContext: delight at the thought of showing his family

Text.Value: I only wish I could kill Lorroakan all over again.
A magical cannon? That could come in useful.
I won't hide behind lies and cheap tricks like Lorroakan. I will rule this tower as it should be - I swear it. Thank you, my friend.

EditorData.NodeContext: determined and grateful

Text.Value: He's dead now. It's over - and you've won.
Will a room of dusty tomes really help that much?
Lorroakan wanted to exploit Aylin just like Ketheric did, so I beat some sense into him. Do you have a problem with that?
Then share it with the Realms. After all, it does little good collecting dust in an old tower.

EditorData.NodeContext: smile - half the reason he's doing this is because the player inspired him

Text.Value: Oh, it'll take longer than if I had a master. But I won't entrust my fate to another - not again.

EditorData.NodeContext: determined with a hint of remembered pain

Text.Value: I suppose I owe Nightsong some thanks for speeding up the process.
What do we do now?
I killed Ketheric, now Lorroakan. Do you want to be the next 'great' wizard to die?
I only wish I'd had the pleasure.
No more - I'll drag you through all Nine Hells myself.

EditorData.NodeContext: fritted teeth - vicious. About to start combat

Text.Value: And if I want the Nightsong for myself?
But now, I don't need him. I have the tower. I have the Nightsong.
Leave.
Lorroakan was a vicious bastard - he beat me for the smallest of transgressions.
Indeed. And all the preparation in the world wouldn't have saved the charlatan from an aasimar.
Seeing what Master Lorroakan is capable of, I know my place is here. Thank you - for settling any doubts.

EditorData.NodeContext: more demure and restrained then our usual rolan - he's sided with lorroakan and is now his eternal apprentice

Text.Value: But know this - Ramazith's Tower, and its master, are now your friends. And when the time comes, we will stand by you as allies.

EditorData.NodeContext: sincere and grateful

Text.Value: Then consider the power that awaits us once I cage the Nightsong and channel her invulnerability.
And for every one I answered 'wrong', he'd beat me. I could've killed him with my own two hands, but I kept thinking it was all a test. It had to be.

EditorData.NodeContext: voice distant with remembered pain

Text.Value: I'm not.
'Bastard'? I thought he was your master.
I will. I'll be the ruler of Ramazith's Tower they deserve - not some vicious recluse who hides from the world.

EditorData.NodeContext: determined

Text.Value: What comes next?
I see things clearly now. If I wish to master the Weave, I must do it myself.

EditorData.NodeContext: determined

Text.Value: What are you going to do to Nightsong?
What's mine is yours - take what you please. Leave only the books and scrolls.

EditorData.NodeContext: determined

Text.Value: Oh, I like the sound of that! I do indeed.

EditorData.NodeContext: a laugh and smile

Text.Value: Finish what Lorroakan started, of course. I shall cage her and channel her invulnerability.
The city is under siege, from the inside out. I need allies.
Here. Take Lorroakan's gold in the meantime - spend it as you wish.
And the tower itself has a cannon! The sheer power is mind-boggling.

EditorData.NodeContext: surprise and awe - he can't believe all this is his now

Text.Value: He knew the risks.
I am - now that the bastard's in bits.

EditorData.NodeContext: relieved - with a hint of sadness at what he's gone through

Text.Value: It's come to this, has it? Fine - I will avenge my master.

EditorData.NodeContext: vicious - about to start combat

Text.Value: What in the hells happened here?

EditorData.NodeContext: looking around in shock and horror - accusation towards the player

Text.Value: What are you going to do with the knowledge you've discovered?
I have access to Ramazith's notes, and I have the best chance of dealing with her before she wakes up and murders us both.
I'm sure this place has some interesting trinkets you can part with...
Lorroakan wanted to imprison and torture my friend Nightsong. I couldn't let him hurt her.
I knew Lorroakan amassed knowledge like a dragon with its hoard, but never could I have imagined such wealth.

EditorData.NodeContext: surprise and awe - he can't believe all this is his now

Text.Value: But first, I must cage the aasimar. After that, I have an eternity to begin.
You must be pleased - you've got what you wanted.
As do I.

EditorData.NodeContext: quiet viciousness

Text.Value: You're welcome.
Indeed. I thought it would be an age before Lorroakan keeled over - leaving me Ramazith's Tower.

Synopsis: Dialog after final confrontation with Rolan. Depending on whether he joined Nightsong team or not or if Lorroakan died or not different branches will be chosen.
